awd_titl_txt: Tuning electronic instabilities in triangular surface lattices via subsurface doping
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Abstract:
This project aims to controllably modify the electronic properties of monatomic thin film materials via chemical doping experiments.  The thin film systems under investigation consist of tin or thallium atoms arranged in various triangular patterns on a silicon substrate.  The monatomic tin layer is of particular interest because there is the potential to obtain novel electronic materials with possibly exotic properties, such as superconductivity via chemical doping.  Exotic magnetism may be obtained through the chemical doping of monatomic thallium films.  Atomic-scale understanding of the quantum mechanical mechanisms that give rise to such emergent electronic behavior is crucial in order to advance a new class of electronic materials as the possible replacement of silicon in, e.g., nano-electronic devices used in information technology.  The proposed science and supporting infrastructure at The University of Tennessee provide an excellent setting for the education and training of internationally competitive graduate students.  A rigorous plan for integrating sponsored research with undergraduate education is being implemented to boost enrolment in the physics major.  The outreach program targets sophomore and junior high school students who are participating in the prestigious Tennessee Governor School for the Sciences and Engineering.  By providing all of these young people with unique research and educational experiences, the investigators aim to entice these deep thinkers and future decision-makers to pursue an advanced degree in the physical sciences. 

Technical Abstract:

A critical aspect for advancing knowledge and practical applications of complex materials is the ability to control their electronic properties via chemical doping.  For a strictly two-dimensional system, chemical doping inevitably introduces structural disorder as the ionized dopant impurities become an integral part of the two-dimensional electron system.  This project builds on the main accomplishments from earlier NSF sponsored research, in which hole doping of a surface layer or thin film was accomplished via subsurface- or ?modulation doping?.  In analogy with studies on complex oxide systems, the investigations aim to widen the concentration range of the hole dopants and expand the modulation doping concept to n-type species, so as to establish a full electronic phase diagram.  This strategy is being employed to dope triangular surface lattices with strong Mott correlations and strong spin-orbit coupling.  The exciting possibilities of d-wave superconductivity in the former, and spin density wave instabilities in the latter will be explored as a function of the doping level.  The project involves thin film growth in ultrahigh vacuum, scanning tunneling microscopy and spectroscopy, and angle-resolved photoemission experiments, all in conjunction with theoretical support from outside collaborators. The proposed science and supporting infrastructure at The University of Tennessee provide an excellent setting for the education and training of internationally competitive graduate students.  A rigorous plan for integrating sponsored research with undergraduate education is being implemented to boost enrolment in the physics major.  The outreach program targets sophomore and junior high school students who are participating in the prestigious Tennessee Governor School for the Sciences and Engineering.  By providing all of these young people with unique research and educational experiences, the investigators aim to entice these deep thinkers and future decision-makers to pursue an advanced degree in the physical sciences.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit.  Doping, the deliberate and proper introduction of a foreign chemical species into a host material, is one of the most effective strategies to manipulate its electronic properties. For instance, silicon is a semiconductor (or electrical insulator at low temperature), but can be made conductive or metallic-like by incorporating boron or phosphorous atoms in tiny amounts. It took years of studies to acquire detailed insights into the physics and chemistry of silicon doping, but the fundamental knowledge gleaned from those studies enabled the semiconductor revolution of the 20th century. While silicon continues to be the material of choice for the semiconductor industry, materials researchers are now directing their efforts to novel ?quantum materials? that may find applications in future technologies, such as nanotechnology and quantum computing. Quantum materials exhibit quantum mechanical behavior at macroscopic scale, for instance, they can become superconducting upon doping. These materials often have a layered crystal structure or can be viewed as a strictly two-dimensional (2D) material. Property control via chemical doping presents a very significant challenge, however, because chemical impurities become increasingly detrimental to the performance of a device once the dimensionality of the device shrinks from 3D to 2D (a film or a slab) or 1D (wire). 

 

This project aimed to develop a successful doping strategy for introducing excess electrons or holes into a monatomic tin layer on a silicon substrate. The tin layer is electrically insulating, but is expected to condense into a macroscopic quantum phase upon doping. During the first phase of the project, it was demonstrated that the Sn layer becomes metallic at a critical density of boron atoms inside the silicon substrate, and that it is on the verge of an ?electronic instabilty? towards a magnetic or superconducting state. The condensation of such macroscopic quantum phases likely requires even higher boron densities, something that will need to be verified in future studies. During the second phase of the project, it was shown that the Sn layer transforms into a novel Kagome structure upon deposition of alkali metal atoms, a process called surface doping. The Kagome lattice can be viewed as a regular arrangement of atoms according to a ?star of David? tiling pattern. Doped kagome systems are extremely interesting and may have exotic magnetic or superconducting properties.

 

Many findings in this study point to interesting similarities to complex oxide materials, including the high-temperature superconductors. However, they are extraordinary within the realm of conventional semiconductor materials. This suggests that exotic quantum matter phases can possibly be realized and engineered on a silicon-based materials platform.

 

BROADER IMPACT.  If history is any guide, the importance of fundamental materials research cannot be underestimated. The knowledge and insights obtained from those studies provide the scientific underpinnings of future discovery and technological breakthrough. As such, they are the key drivers of technological innovation and economic prosperity, and thus benefit society as a whole. The project also provided excellent educational and training opportunities for young scientists, students and postdocs. They have learned how to set up a scientific study, build and operate complex scientific equipment, synthesize new materials, conduct scientific experiments, acquire and analyze new data, prepare scientific reports, and  communicate their findings orally and in writing. These well-trained young minds will soon enter the workforce and are poised to become tomorrow?s leaders in science and technology. The project also contributed to a significant development of scientific infrastructure at the Joint Institute for Advanced Materials, a joint venture between the University of Tennessee and Oak Ridge National Laboratory. It is now accessible to researchers from all universities, national laboratories, and industry.
